hi, i'm ashi krishnan, i work at apollo, and i'm here to talk about the future of federation. we've been doing a lot of work over the last year, all aimed at making it easier for you to weave together many large graphs and end up with exactly the data you need, in exactly the shape you need it. after all, that's the promise of graphql. first, let's look at the state of graphql and federation today. graphql gives us a common language to describe all the data available through an API. say we're an organization who launches people into space. we'll presumably have a database tracking who we have launched (or will launch) into space. and then we'll write a graphql schema to expose that data for our website where you can see who we've launched into space. the graphql schema might look like this: 

  type Query {
    launches: [Launch!]!
    astronaut(byName: String!): Astronaut
    missions: [Mission!]!
    ships: [Ship!]!
  }

  type Launch {
    id: ID!
    site: String
    mission: Mission
    ship: Ship
    astronauts: [Astronaut]!
  }
  
  type Ship {
    id: ID!
    name: String
    type: String
  }
 
  type Astronaut {
    id: ID!
    name: String!    
    trips: [Launch]!
  }
  
  type Mission {
    name: String
  }
this looks like a tree, but when we parse it, we can see that it creates a structure with cross-links— —that is, it gets linked into a graph. in this graph, types are nodes—they are places you can *be*. fields are edges—they are ways you can *move*. resolvers teach us *how to walk along an edge*. 
  
    type Query {
      books(forAstronaut: ID!): [Book]
    }
    
    type Book {
      title: String
      author: Author
      themes: [String!]
    }
    
    type Author {
      name: String
      books: [Book!]
    }
  

  
    query {
      astronaut(byName: "Sally") {
        trips {
          mission { name }
        }
      }
    }
so when we receive a query the resolvers know how to take us to the data if we didn't have graphql, we would still be able to expose this data. we'd just have to come up with our own interface to request it—maybe some RESTful api. but graphql gives us a common language for expressing our schema. that common language makes it easier to get data out of graphql endpoints. it also means that endpoints can be merged together and treated as a single graph. after we've been launching people into space for a while, we notice that most of the people who want to go to space are sci-fi fans, so we want to roll out a feature where we track what folks are reading and use it to inspire future missions. this project is run by a separate team, so they produce a separate schema: which links into another graph there's a subtle connection to our space graph here: specifically, we can look up the books for a particular astronaut's ID. but that's not really represented in the graph itself. the two graphs are disconnected. so if we want to do a query across them, we have to do that query separately, and manually 
  
    query GetAstronautId($name: String!) {
      astronaut(byName: $name) { id }
    }

    # variables: { name: "sally" }
  

  
    query GetAstronautTitles($id: ID!) {
      books(forAstronaut: $id) {
        title
        author { name }
      }
    }
first, we query spacey to get the id of an astronaut we're interested in then we have to shuttle that data over to bookish ourselves to query for the astronaut's titles this gets us the data we need, but it's not exactly ideal. it breaks the graphql promise of making one query to feed your frontend federation solves this. to link these two graphs with federation, we don't need to change our spacey schema at all but we do need to make a few changes to our bookish schema. these changes teach the federation gateway how to build *another* graph 
  
    extend type Query {
      books(forAstronaut: ID!): [Book]
    }

    extend type Astronaut @key(fields: "id") {
      id: ID! @external
      books: [Book]
    }
    
    type Book {
      title: String
      author: Author
      themes: [String!]
    }
    
    type Author {
      name: String
      books: [Book!]
    }
the federated graph the federated graph joins our other two graphs. you can think of it as a projection of both of them. a pretty faithful one—it contains all the types and fields from all our services, with the same types, names, arguments, and so on. it also knows where those types and fields are *from* and, thanks to keys, how to get from one graph to another. now we can express our request as a single query against the federated graph and when we run the query the gateway knows what queries to issue against its subgraphs to resolve the data we asked for. that's federation as it stands today. federation is already incredibly powerful. it lets you fold multiple graphs into one—it's effectively giving us the "reduce" part of "map/reduce", but for the structure of our data itself. as with mapreduce, this lets you parallelize work—only in this case, the work is *growing the graph*. with federation, you can have multiple teams each working on growing the graph—it grows in parallel. which means, your graph can explode. 
  
    query {
      astronaut(byName: "sally") {
        books {
          title
          author { name }
        }
      }
    }
this is amazing, but it can also be a lot! the amount of accessible data in your organization and frankly in the world is enough to make anyone's brain start dropping frames just like my computer. massive graphs create new, massive problems. you still have one graph to reason about, but now it's made of tens or hundreds of subgraphs, each likely maintained by a separate team. you have to make sure they fit together, make sure nobody steps on anyone else's toes. there are also some use cases that federation doesn't handle yet. when we federate graphs today, we end up with a federated graph that looks a lot like our subgraphs. same names, same types, same fields. but what if we want to change that? what if we want more flexibility in how we merge our graphs together? some of you might remember schema stitching—some of you might *still be using* schema stitching. schema stitching was kindof a precursor to federation: a more bare-metal way of merging subgraphs together. with schema stitching, you could really do whatever you wanted to the subgraphs, pruning and reshaping fields, changing types. but schema stitching was very ad-hoc—literally, you write some javascript that manipulates the schema ASTs more or less directly. that's extremely flexible, but also quite hard to reason about. with federation, we can and do run validations on the composed graph. schema stitching doesn't really allow for that, because outside of the requirement that it be a valid graphql schema, we really have no way of knowing if the stitched schema is correct. what if we could have both? the verifiability of federation with the flexibility of schema stitching?
earlier this year, we sat down and asked ourselves this question: what's next? how do build on federation? how do we develop tools to wrangle these increasingly massive graphs? we've called the result project constellation. project constellation is an evolution of federation, developed with a few goals in mind we knew we wanted to improve performance to that end, we're rewriting the query planner in rust. this doesn't mean *you* have to write anything in rust; it also doesn't mean we've given up on javascript. our intention here is to provide a drop-in replacement for the current query planner within apollo server. when it's ready, all you'll have to do is update your gateway to get the benefits. now, we're not just dropping in rust and expecting things to get faster. we're also doing a lot of testing. we're building out benchmarks and using them to explore design patterns that can exploit the many, many cores today's servers are stacked with longer term, we're developing workflows to reduce the work the gateway does—such as schema composition—by moving it to an ahead of time compilation step that ties into our next goal, which is to make federation *stronger* we'd like to be able to provide better validation information earlier in the development process when you're working on some part of your graph, you should be able to compile the whole thing during development, locally, and see if there are any problems and the tools to make that possible will give you a lot more insight than you have today into how the graph of everything liks together that's important, because we're also making federation flexibili...er we want to bring back a lot of the flexibility of schema stitching giving you more options for how to project large graphs. flexibility also means compatibility. this was an important design criteria: we absolutely did not want to introduce any mandatory changes on the client side. all the new shiny features we're about to talk about will work with existing graphql clients. everything we're talking about today will work with your current clients and your current federated services. but they'll also work with services that aren't currently federated. federation does require a bit of work: you have to declare keys and define entity resolvers. and you may still want to do this, even in the future! but you won't have to. constellation gives us tools to federate services that have not implemented federation! it lets us weave together graphs that have no idea they're in a federation at all. let's see how. let's go back and look at our books schema. to federate this service, we had to define a key on `Astronaut` and implement `__entities`. this teaches the federation gateway how to enter the bookish service with an external type—namely, Astronaut. something that's a little frustrating about this is that we actually already have all the information we need to resolve Astronaut.books. There's a `books(forAstronaut ID)` right there in our Query type. probably, we're calling the same underlying function in our Astronaut.books resolver. but there's no way to teach graphql about that. there's just no way to say, "in order to resolve this field, use data from this other field". this is highly related to one of the most common questions I get asked: "how do I call into a resolver from another resolver?" and the answers we have today are pretty unsatisfying. basically: do it yourself. you can get a handle on the schema, and then call `execute` on it with your query. of course that doesn't really work in a federated context. the schema you have access to is the schema for whatever service you're in. if you want to make a federated query, you have to basically call up the gateway as though you're a client. that also means that any sub-queries that happen like this aren't included in query planning, so if this is something you end up doing a lot, you'll end up waterfalling—not great. anyway, turns out we can fix it. 
  
    extend type Query {
      books(forAstronaut: ID!): [Book]
    }

    extend type Astronaut {
      id: ID! @external
      books: [Book] @from(query: "books(forAstronaut: id)")
    }
    
    type Book {
      title: String
      author: Author
      themes: [String!]
    }
    
    type Author {
      name: String
      books: [Book!]
    }
oooh. what we've done here is introduce a new directive—the @from directive, which says, "in order to resolve this field, run this other query." if you look carefully, you'll notice that this isn't actually a full query—we couldn't execute it from a client, because it doesn't select any fields. but here, that's okay! this query isn't going to get run directly. instead, it provides input to the query planner. when the gateway receives an end-user query which traverses Astronaut.books, it will insert this partial query into the query plan, and along with whatever selection set the frontend is asking for. another thing: we no longer need key, because our query explicitly references `id`. i did that to demonstrate that we don't need it, but there are still good reasons to define keys and entities. notably, entities are batch-resolved, so we might see better performance if we're working with large sets of astronauts. this turns out to be pretty powerful, especially when you start thinking about larger graphs. say project gutenberg has a graphql api. with constellation, we can federate our own graph with it—no reason we can't, right? we just need a url. 
  
    extend type Query {
      books(forAstronaut: ID!): [Book]
    }

    extend type Astronaut {
      id: ID! @external
      books: [Book] @from(query: "books(forAstronaut: id)")
    }
    
    type Book {
      title: String
      author: Author
      themes: [String!]
      text: String
        @from(query: "
          gutenberg::search(
            author: author.name,
            title: title).nodes.0.text")
    }
    
    type Author {
      name: String
      books: [Book!]
    }
doing that lets us add a `text` field to our books. there's a bit more going on here. we've introduced some new query syntax—that's fine, clients don't ever have to know about it, it's just for use in the schema. i want to emphasize that we haven't entirely finalized this syntax the new pieces are graph identifiers and dotted paths. here, the graph identifier tells us to query the gutenberg subgraph. we need the dotted paths to dig into the search results and lift the text of the first one up so it can be its own string field. keeping with the spirit of graphql, dot paths here act like optional chains—if any step is nullable, the whole thing is nullable i think you can start to see how powerful this can be. but we're not quite done. we're aiming to make the developer experience rather nicer than this. for example, the query chain is a bit long, and it's actually clear how we can shorten it. if this were a programming language, we'd just use a variable, but we don't have those. maybe we can define a field? we don't know the type of this field. we could go and figure it out—it's some kind of connection—but this is another case where the compiler *already knows*, so maybe we could just ask it to fill something in? 
  
    extend type Query {
      books(forAstronaut: ID!): [Book]
    }

    extend type Astronaut {
      id: ID! @external
      books: [Book] @from(query: "books(forAstronaut: id)")
    }
    
    type Book {
      title: String
      author: Author
      themes: [String!]
      gutenbergBooks: ??? # what goes here??
        @from(query: "
          gutenberg::search(
            author: author.name,
            title: title)
        ")
      text: String @from(field: "gutenbergBooks.nodes.0.text")
    }
    
    type Author {
      name: String
      books: [Book!]
    }
that's what __Infer does. __Infer will be erased when we compose this schema. the compiler will substitute in the acutal return type of the query. i think you can see how this gets pretty powerful, pretty fast. but it's also getting increasingly hard to read. we're doing a lot of work inside strings within directives, which feels a bit off. and now there's underscores happening, which are always a little intimidating. what if... what if we could write this? 
  
    extend type Query {
      books(forAstronaut: ID!): [Book]
    }

    extend type Astronaut {
      id: ID! @external
      books: [Book] @from(query: "books(forAstronaut: id)")
    }
    
    type Book {
      title: String
      author: Author
      themes: [String!]
      gutenbergBooks: __Infer
        @from(query: "
          gutenberg::search(
            author: author.name,
            title: title)
        ")
      text: String @from(field: "gutenbergBooks.nodes.0.text")
    }
    
    type Author {
      name: String
      books: [Book!]
    }
we call this a star schema. it's a proper superset of graphql. right now, you might be thinking, "oh, cool!" or you might be thinking: "ashi! you promised back compatibility! you can't go adding features to the language all willy-nilly" ah, but this *is* back compatible. all of this compiles down to graphql. everything on the left is syntactic sugar for this: it's just a bit cleaner, a bit shorter. this is all possible because we're introducing a compile step. or rather, we're making the existing compile step—which happens in the gateway—more explicit, and more powerful. to be clear: we're not completely set on this syntax—though it does *feel* rather nice, doesn't it? part of why we're sharing this early work is to get some feedback. and the other reason is to get you excited. this is really cool! i mean, can you imagine the process you'd have to go through to write a service that does something like this today? here, with really just a few extensions to federation, we're able to do it without writing any resolvers, without pushing any binaries. these tools let us express joins and delegation and a whole host of data *flow* concepts within the data layer, where they can be statically analyzed, planned, and validated. that's exciting now, and it's going to be vital in the future as the space of data that we're working with continues to grow in size and complexity, these are the kinds of tools we'll need to wrangle, project, and reshape those graphs. federation is the first step. and this? this is the next one. thank you. 
  
    extend type Query {
      books(forAstronaut: ID!): [Book]
    }

    extend type Astronaut {
      id: ID! @external
      books: [Book] = query::books(forAstronaut: id)
    }
    
    type Book {
      title: String
      author: Author
      themes: [String!]
      gutenbergBooks = gutenberg::search(
        author: author.name, title
      )
      text: String = gutenberg.text
    }
    
    type Author {
      name: String
      books: [Book!]
    }
@rakshesha ashi.io
